XXXIII 1 406
(250) Thorns 24th FebyFebruary - On reaching un-
flooded lands beyond the
plains we found the villages
there ^ acknowledged the authority
of the chief named Katende,
and we discovered also
to our surprise that an
an the plalmost level plain
we had crossedpassed formeds the watershed
between the Leeambye
an Southern and Northern
rivers, - for, we now
entered on a district
in which the rivers
flowed in a Northerly
direction into the Kasai
CKasaiKasai or Loke which
near which we had
now come, ^ while and the
rivers we had hitherto
crossed ˅ were all strikethrough running
southerly-wards - Having
met ˅ with kind treatment
and aid at the first village
Katema's guides returned
and we were led to
the N N- N- W-North North West by the inhabitants
and descended ^ into the very
first really deep valley
we had come to beyond
Kolobeng - A stream
ran along the bottom
of a slope of three or four
hundred yards from the
plains above

2 407
We crossed this by a rustic
bridge at present submerged
thigh deep by the rains - The
trees growing along the stream
of this lovely valley were thickly
planted and very high - Many
had sixty or eighty feet of
clean straight trunk and
beautiful flowers adorned
the ground beneath them -
Ascending the opposite side
we came in two tihourshours'
time to another valley equally
beautiful and with a
stream also atin its centre
It may seem mere trifling
to note such an imp un-
important thing as a the
occurrence of a valley,
there being so many in
every country und-erunder the
sun, but as these were
here b were but branches
of that in which the
CasaiKasai or Loke flows
and ^ both that river withand its
feeders derive their water
in a singular manner
from the valley sides
I may be excused calling
particular attention to
them the more furrowed
nature of the country -

3408
At different points on
the slopes of these vall^eysiesvalleys
which we now for the
first time enter there are
oozing fountains with
surrounded by clumps of
the same ever green
straight larged leaved trees
we have noticed along
the streams - They are
These spots are generally covered with
a mat of grassy vegetation
and possess more
the character of a bogs
than of a fountains - They
communicate with the
slowly discharge
into the ^ stream below and are
so numerous along
both banks as to give
a peculiar char character
to the landscape - These groups
of trees sylvan vegetation isare generally of
a rounded form and
the trunks ^ of the trees are tall and
straight while the trees
those on the level plains
ababove are low and
scraggy in their growth.
There can be little doubt
but that the water which
stands for months on
the plains soaks in
and finds its way into
the rivers & rivulets by
means of these percolating
4 409
through the soil and out
by these oozing bogs into
the rivers, and the difference
between the growths of the
trees, though they be of
different species may
be a proof that the
scragginess stuntedness
of those on the plains
is more owing to being
too long in the course of
each year more subjected
to drought than moisture

Reaching the village
Kabinje of Kabinje in the evening
he sent us a present of
tobacco - Mutokuane or
bang (Cannabis sativa) byand
maize by the man who
went forward to announce
our arrival and an message
expressing satisfaction at the
prospect of having trade
with the coast - The westing
we were making brought
us among people who
are frequently visited by
the Mambari as slave dealers
This trade causes bloodshed
for when a poor family
is selected as the victims
it is necessary to get rid
of the older members of it,
because they are supposed
to be able to give annoyance
5 410
to the chief afterwards by means
of enchantments - The belief
in the power of charms for
good or evil produces not
only honesty by a great
amount of gentle dealing
The powerful are often
restrained in their despotism
by a fear that the weak
& helpless may injure
them by their medical
knowledge They have many
fears - A man at one
of the villages we came to
shewedshowed us the grave
of his child and with
much apparent feeling
told us she had been burned
to death in her hut - He
had come with all his family
and built huts around it
in order to weep for her - He
thought if the grave were
left unwatched the witches
would come and bewitch
them by putting medicines
on the body - They have
a more decided belief in
the continued existence of
departed spirits than any
of the more southerly Tribes
Even the Barotse possess
theit in a strong degree for
one of my men of that
6 411
tribe on experiencing headache
said with a sad and thoughtful
countenance, said "My father is
scolding me because I do not
give him any of the food I eat"
I asked where his father was
"Among the Barimo" was the reply -

Chester When we wished to move on
Kabinje refused a guide to the
next village because he was
at war with it but after
much persuasion he consented
/ provided but with the stipulation that
the guide should be allowed
to turn as soon as he came
in sight of the enemy's village
This we felt to be a
misfortune ˅ foras the people
all suspect a man who
comes telling his own
tale but there being no
help for it we went on
and found the headman
of a village on the rivulet
Kalomba called Kangenke
a very different man
from what his enemy
represented - We found too
that the idea of buying
and selling took the place
7 412
of giving for friendship - As
I had nothing to purchase
food except the parcel
of beads which were reserved
for worse times I began
to fear that we should soon
be compelled to suffer
more from hunger than
we had done - The people
here demanded more pgun-
-powder for everything
If we had possessed any
quantity of that article
we should have got on
well for here it is
of great value - On our
return near this spot we
found a good sized fowl
was sold for a single
charge of gunpowder
Next to that English
calico was in great
demand - and so were
beads but money was
of no value whatever
Gold is quite unknown
even inby name in these
central parts - It is thought
to be brass and I am certain
that if you offered a man
his choice of a sovereign and a brass button
he would take the latter
as most valuable because
it has an eye to it

8 413
27th FebyFebruary - Kangenke promptly furn-
-ished guides this morning
so we went briskly on a
short distance and came
to a part of the Kasye, CasaiKasai, or
Loke where he had appointed
two canoes to convey us
across - This is a most
beautiful river in size and
very much like the clydeClyde
in Scotland in size The
slope of the valley down
to the stream is about
five hundred yards and
finely wooded - It is about perhaps
one hundred yards broad - &
It was winding slowly from
side to side in the beautiful
green valley ain a course
to the North or& Nortr NorNorth North East
In both the directions onfrom
which it came & went
it seemed to be alternately
embowered in sylvan vegetation
rich &fertile or ˅ beautifulrich meadows -
covered with tall grass.
The men pointed out its
course and said "though
you sail along it for
months you will turn
without seeing the end
of it - "

9 414
While at the ford of the
Kasai we were subjected
to a trick of which we
had been forewarned
by the people of Shinte -
A knife had been dropped
by one of Kangenke's
people in order to
entrap my men - It iswas
put down near our encampment as if lost
the owner in the mean
time watching till some-
one ^ one of my men picked it up - Nothing
was said untilluntil we
were now parted one
half on this side and
the other on that bank
of the river - Then the
charge was made to
me that one of my men
had stolen a knife
Certain of my people's honesty
I desired the man who
was making a great noise
to search the luggage for it
The unlucky lad who had
taken the bait then came
forward and confessed
that he had the knife in
a basket which was
already taken over the beyond the river
When it was broughtreturned
/ returned back the origin owner would
10 415
not recievereceive it back unless accom-
-panied with a fine - The
lad offered beads but these
were refused with scorn
A shell being round his
neck similar to that which
Shinte had given me was
the object demanded - and
the victim of the trick as we
we all knew it to be was
obliged to part with his costly
ornament - I could not
save him from the loss as
all had been forewarned
and it is the universal custom
among the Makololo and
many other tribes to shewshow
whatever they may find
to the chief person of the
party and make a sort
of offer of it to him -
This lad ought to have done
so to me asnd the rest would
cehave done of the party always
did observe this custom -
I felt annoyed as the imposition
but the order we always
observed in crossing a
river forced me to submit
The head of the party remained
to the last so if I had
not come to terms I would
have been as I always was
in crossing rivers ^ which we could
11 416
not swim completely in the
power of the enemy - It
was but rarely we could
get a headman so witless
as to cross a river with
us and remain on the opposite
bank in a convenient
position to be seized as
an hostage in case of
my being caught -

Dennett This trick is but one
of a number equally dishonourable
which are practised by
tribes ˅ which that lie adjacent
to the more civilized
settlements - and The Balonda
farther East told us inus by way
by way of warning giving usof warning that
many parties of the
more central tribes had
at various periods set
out in order to trade
with the whitemenwhite men themselves
instead of through the Mambari,
X but had always been
obliged to return without reaching
their destination ˅ throughin consequence of in consqconsequence
so many ways pretexts
being invented by by ^ the tribes
encountered ^ in the way for fining
them of their ivory

This ford was in 11° 15' - 47"
South Latitude but the weather
was so excessively cloudy
we got no observation for Longitude

12 417
We were now in want
of food, for to the great
surprise of my companions
the people of Kangenke
gave nothing except by
way of sale, and they
charged were the most exhorbitantexorbitant
X in their demands or prices
for of the little meal and manioc
they brought; - The only
article my men had was
a little fat saved from
the ox we slaughtered at
Katema's, so I had to
give ^ them a portion of the
stock of beads - One
day (29th) of Westing brought us from
the Kasai to near the
village of Katende but
and we saw we were
in a land where no hope
dependancedependence can be placed
of ^ the game animal food could be enter-
tained of getting
on supplies
of animal
food, for ^ one of our
guides caught a light
blue coloured mole and
two mice - for his supper;
His careful wrapping of
them up in a leaf
& slinging them on his
spear told that we could
not hope to enjoy any
larger game, - We saw
no evidence of any animals
besides -; and on coming
X
13 418
X
to the villages
in front this we often saw the boys
and girls engaged in
digging up these tiny
quadrupeds

Katende sent for me
on the day following our
arrival and being quite
willing to visit him I
walked ˅ for this purpose about three miles
from our encampment
for the purpose When
we approached the village
we were desired to enter
a hut, ˅ and as it was raining
at the time we did so. This we did as
it was raining and aAfter
a long time spent in
giving and recievingreceiving
messages from the great
man we were told that
he l wanted either a man
X or a tusk, , or beads, or
copper rings, or a shell
as payment for leave
to pass through his country;
No one was allowed
that liberty to pass through his country
or even ˅ to behold him without
X something of the sort
being presented, Having
humbly explained heour
circumstances, and that
he could not cat expect
to "catch a humble cow
by the horns," a proverb
14 419
similar to ours that "you cantcan't
draw milk out of a stone"
we were told to go home,
and he would speak
again to us next day -
I could not avoid a
hearty laugh at the cool
impudence of the savage,
and made the best of
my way home in
the still pouring rain
My men were rather
nettled at this want of
hospitality, but after talking
over the matter with
one of Katende's servants
he proposed that some
small article should
be given and the attempt
made to please Katende;
I turned out my shirts &
selected the worst one
as a sop ^ for him, and invited him
Katende ^ to come and choose the
best of anything else I had,
but when I should
reach themy own chief
naked ^ and was asked why
asked ^ I came what I had done
with my clothes that I
came naked I would
be obliged to confess that
I had left them with Katende
The shirt went off to
254 him, and [some of my people
15 420
went along with the servant; -
They soon returned, saying
that the shirt had been
accepted, and guides and
food too would be sent
to us next day - He, moreover,
expressed a hope to see me on
my return, He is reported to be
very corpulent - ; The traders
who have come here
seem to have been very
timid, yielding to every
demand made on the most
frivolous pretences; - One
of my men seeing another
much like an acquaintance
at home addressed him
by the name of the latter
in sport - telling him at
the same time why he did
so - ; This was pronounced
to be a grave offence, and
a large fine demanded;
When the case came before
me I could see no harm
in what had been done,
and told my people not
to answer the young
fellow - The latter felt
himself disarmed, for
it is chiefly in a brawl
X they have power; for
their words are spoken
in anger which rouse
the passions of the complainant's
16 421
friends - In this case after
vociferating some time
the would be offended party
came and said to my
man that if they gave
each other something all
would be right, but my
man taking no notice
of him he went off
much crest fallen

Cross My men were much
astonished as myself at the
demand for payment
for leave to pass and
the almost entire want of
observance of the rules
of hospitality - Katende
gave us only a little meal
and manioc and a fowl -
X and Bbeing detained two
days by heavy rains
we felt that a good stock
of patience was necessary
in travelling through this
country in the rainy season

Parting without seeing
Katende we crossed the small
rivulet ^ (the Sengko) by which we had
encamped and after two
hours came to another the
Totelo - This was somewhat
larger and had a bridge
over it - At the further end
of this structure stood a negro
17 422
and demanded toll fees - He
said the bridge was his - the
path his and the guides were
his children and if we did
not pay him he would
prevent farther progress
This was a piece of civilization
I was not prepared to
meet and stood a few seconds
looking at our bold toll-
keeper When one of my
men took off three copper
armlets bracelets and paid
for the whole party - He was
a better man than he
at first seemed for he immediately
went to his garden
and brought us some
leaves of tobacco inas a
X present -

When we had got
fairly away from villages
the guides sat down
and stated their told us that
there were three paths in
front and if we did not
at once present them with
a cloth they would leave
X us to take which ever we
might like best - As I
had pointed out the
direction in which LoandoLuanda
lay and had only employed
them for the sake of knowing
18 423
the paths between villages
which lay along our route
and always objected when
they led us in any other
than the LoandoLuanda direction
I wished my men now to
go on without them ^ guides and
tha we should choose
the path which would
StStet/ might would seem to lead us in the direction
we had always followed
But Mashauana fearing lest
we we should ˅ might wander asked
leave to give his cloth and
when the guides saw that
they he came forward shouting
X "Averie Averie"

In the afternoon of this
day we came to a valley
about a mile wide filled
with clear fast flowing
water - The men on foot
were chin deep and we three
on ox-back got our wet to
the middle the weight on the
animal preventing him
from swimming - A thunder
shower came ^ descending on and
X completed the partial
drenching of the plains
and gave a cold uncomfortable
packing in a wet blanket
that night - Next day
we found another flooded
valley ˅ about half a mile wide with a small & now deep
19 424
rivulet in its middle - This
valley was half a mile wide
X and following rapidly to the
S. S. ESouth South EastS. S.South South East South South East theor direction
towards the Kasai - The middle
part of this flood being
the bed of what inat other
times wasis the rivulet was
so rapid that we crossed
by holding on to the oxen
and the current soon
dashed them to the opposite
bank - we then jumped off
and and being relieved
of their burdens
we could pulled them on to
the shallower part - The
rest of the valley was thigh
deep and boggy but
holding on by the belt which
fastened on the blanket
to the ox ^ we each floundered through
the nasty slough as well
as we could - These boggy
parts lying parallel to the
stream were the first
we had come to - Those mentioned
already were mere circumscribed
patches these extended for
miles along each bank
but even here though
the rapidity of the current
was very considerable the
thick sward of glrass
was laids along the sides
of the stream and the soil
20 425
was not abraded so much
as to discolour the flood -
When we came to the
opposite side of this valley
some pieces of ^ the ferrugineousferruginous
conglomerate which forms
the X to capping to all other rocks
in a large district around
and North of this cropped
out and the oxen bit at
them as if as much
struck by the appearance
˅ of stone ^ a as ˅ much as we were -
We had not met with
a stone csince leaving
Shinte's - The country is
covered with deep alluvial
soil

In the afternoon we came
to another stream Nguana Loke
(or child of Loke) with a bridge
over it - The men had
to swim off to each end
of the bridge and when on
it were
breast deep and some
preferred holding on by
the tails of the oxen - over
the whole distance - I atintended
to do this too but riding
to the deep part before I
could dismount and siezeseize
the helpm the ox dashed
off with his companions
and his body went so deep
21 426
that I failed in my attempt even
to catch the blanket belt
and if I pulled the bridle
the ox seemed as if he
would come back^wards upon
me - so I struck out for
the opposite bank alone
My poor fellows were
dreadfully alarmed when
they saw me parted from
the cattle and about
twenty of them made a
simultaneous rush in
to the water for my rescue
and just as I reached
the opposite bank one
seized my arm and the
other threwput his ˅ arms around my
body - When I stood up
it was most gratifying
to see them all struggling
towards me - Some had
leapt off the bridge and
allowed their cloaks to
float down the stream
and pPart of my goods
abandoned
in the hurry ^ were brought up from
the bottom after I was
safe - Great was the
pleasure expressed when
they had found I could
swim like themselves
without the aid of a tail
and I did and do feel grateful
to these poor heathen for the promptudepromptitude
22 427
with which they dashed in
to save as they thought my
life - I found my clothes
cumbersome in the water -
They could swim quicker
from being naked - They
swim dolike dogs not frog
fashion as we do -

In the evening we crossed
the small rivulet Lozeze and
came to some villages of
Kasabi the Kasabi whfrom whom
we got some manioc for
beads - They tried to frighten
us by telling of the deep
rivers we should have
to cross in front - I was
drying my clothes by basting
turning myself
round and
round myself before the fire - My men
laughed at the idea of being
frightened by rivers - "We can
all swim" - "Who carried the
white man across the river?
but himself?" I felt proud of their
praise -

Thorns SatSaturday - 4th March - Came to the outskirts
of the territory of the Chiboque
We crossed the Konde and
Kaluze rivulets - The former
is a deep small stream with
a bridge the latter insignificant
The valleys in which these
rivulets run are beautifully
23 428
fertile - My companions
are continually lamenting
over themir uncultivated
state in such words as
these - "What a fine country
for cattle! My heart is
sore to see such fruitful
valleys for corn layinglying
waste"! When At the
time these words were
noted I had come to
the belief that the reason
why the inhabitants of
this fine country opossess
no herds of cattle was
owing to the despotic
sway of their chiefs - And
that the common
people would not be allowed
to keep any domestic
animals even supposing
they could acquire them
but on musing on the
subject since I have
been led to the conjecture
that the rich fertile country
Londa must formerly
have ^ been infested by the Tsetse
but that as the people
killed off the game on
which in the absence
of man the Tsetse must
subsist, the insect was
starved out of the country
24 429
It is now found only where
wild animals abound
and the Balonda having cleared
several parts of the country of all the
large game we happened to
come just when it was
possible to admit of cattle
Hence the success of
both coKatema, Shinte & Matiamvo
with their herds - It would
not be surprising though
they know nothing of the
circumstance for a tribe
on the ZambesiZambezi which I
encountered whose country
was swarming with cattle
believed that they could not
keep any because "no
one loved them well
enough to give them the
medicine of cattle" and
even the Portuguese at LoandoLuanda
accounted for
the death of believed that the cattle
brought from the Interior to
the sea coast were unable
by the prejudicial
nature of the to live in the sea air! One
ox which I took down to
the sea from the Interior
died at LoandoLuanda with all
the symptoms of the poison
injected as I saw myself
by the Tsetse in a district
within a hundred miles of
the Coast
